page.title: 05Farming Methods (Harberton)
page.content: Farming in the area is still a mixture of dairy, beef and corn. On dairy farms modern milking systems are usual, with some 100 to 150 cows - mainly Friesians, being milked morning and evening in specialised parlours. The milk is pumped directly into large refrigerated tanks for collection by bulk tankers once a day. Corn (barley mainly but some oats and wheat) is grown either for sale to corn merchants or for livestock food on the farm. The practice of making silage is now widespread, although hay is still an important crop.The big round bales are becoming a familiar sight , some of these being stored in large plastic bags. Field size has increased but most fields are still bounded by traditional high Devonshire hedges cut by modern flail cutters.
